references: Table 1 summarizes our results compared with different recent methods in the VQA task. In the GQA dataset, our proposed method outperforms the recent approach HAN [25] on the test-dev set by +2.6%percent2.6+2.6\%. Regarding the multiple-choice Visual7W dataset, our method outperforms the work CTI [11] by 2.8%percent2.82.8\% in the validation set and 2.6%percent2.62.6\% in the test set, respectively. The results show that our CFR can deal with compositional reasoning questions through the selected information from both coarse-grained learning and fine-grained learning. It is worth noting that our CFR achieves new state-of-the-art results in GQA and Visual7W datasets.

references: Table 2 shows the contribution of each module when different inputs are used. By using only the question and image feature (coarse-grained learning), our framework only achieves 62.6%percent62.662.6\% accuracy. When we combine the question and image features with their corresponding predicates (fine-grained learning), the accuracy increase to 67.2%percent67.267.2\%. This result indicates the effectiveness of predicates. By applying the filtered information of both question and image, the performance of fine-grained learning increases to 69.5%percent69.569.5\%. This result shows that by reducing the negative influence of noisy information, the prediction accuracy can be improved. To effectively leverage all coarse-grained and fine-grained information, the Semantic Module is integrated into the framework and achieves 73.6%percent73.673.6\% accuracy. This result validates the potency of Semantic Reasoning in selecting information for answering the complicated question. Overall, our introduced framework outperforms the baseline coarse-grained learning method by a large margin, i.e., +11.0%percent11.0+11.0\% accuracy.
